headline.seo: Bloomberg Plans a Ban on Large Sugared Drinks
headline.print_headline: Mayor Planning A Ban on Big Sizes Of Sugary Drinks
headline.main: New York Plans to Ban Sale of Big Sizes of Sugary Drinks

docs.abstract: New York City plans to enact a far-reaching ban on the sale of large sodas and other sugary drinks at restaurants, movie theaters and street carts, in the most ambitious effort yet by the Bloomberg administration to combat rising obesity; sale of any cup or bottle of sweetened drink larger than 16 fluid ounces will be prohibited under the first-in-the-nation plan, which could take effect as soon as March 2013.
docs.lead_paragraph: A proposal that would take effect as soon as next March is the most ambitious effort yet by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration to combat rising obesity.
docs.snippet: A proposal that would take effect as soon as next March is the most ambitious effort yet by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration to combat rising obesity.

headline.main: Vital Signs | Childbirth: Method of Delivery May Affect Obesity Risk

docs.abstract: Dr Susanna Y Huh study in The Archives of Disease in Childhood finds that babies delivered by Caesarean section may have an increased risk of obesity by age three. (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Babies delivered by Caesarean section may have an increased risk of obesity by age 3, a new study has found. Among 1,255 women recruited in early pregnancy for the study, 284 gave birth by Caesarean section. By age 3, 15.7 percent of those children were obese (with a body mass index in the 95th percentile or greater), compared with 7.5 percent of those delivered vaginally.
